ygData.subject: Re: rtNEAT with one individual?
ygData.msgSnippet: In general it is true that in a game with only two individual bodies (where one may be a human), rtNEAT-based evolution would likely be very slow since the

In general it is true that in a game with only two individual bodies 
(wher=
e one may be a human), rtNEAT-based evolution would likely be 
very slow si=
nce the population of individuals would need to be cycled 
through in the s=
ingle available body on the field.  So unless the 
cycling happened extreme=
ly fast, evolution would not appear real-time.

However, there are recent e=
volutionary selection methods that are 
based on reinforcement learning tha=
t perhaps could be complementary 
with rtNEAT even if it was running on onl=
y one body at a time.  For 
example:

http://www.cs.utexas.edu/~shimon/pubs=
/whitesonjmlr06.pdf

This paper covers several topics, but the relevant one=
 is "online 
evolutionary computation," which uses a reinforcement-learning=
 
strategy to decide who should be in control of the single body at any 
on=
e time.  This technique combined with rtNEAT could perhaps yield 
real-time=
 learning off a single individual body.

Still, it is a general rule that t=
he less time individuals spend on 
the field, the less fast evolution can p=
rogress.

ken 

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Richard Gong" <gongrichard@..=
.> wrote:
>
> I was reading about rtNEAT, and I noticed that it needs multi=
ple 
agents to be tested simultaneously. What if it's a two player game, 
l=
ike computer against human? Can rtNEAT be applied there? I'm thinking 
it'd=
 be really slow, since each genome would have to be tested out one 
at a ti=
me against the human, before you can get a score.
> 
> Richard
>
